text:
Although I’ve been using streaming for set and forget type trades, I’ve been using polling for more active trading. I’m now trying to wean myself off this approach and use streaming for all types. However, polling has the advantage that I can get the start of a market and my trades in that market with a single API call, whereas I would need to combine data from a stream with market data and an order stream.

I’m wondering how other people architect their applications to do this. Do you read both streams in a single loop? Or do you run each in its own process and share snapshots via a common cache? Do you initiate market streams for a single event, or leave them running all day choose within your application when you access the data? Do you use messaging to push data from the streams into a trading app, or pull data from a cache or other data store when needed?

Not expecting answers to all those questions … just hoping to get some insight in architectures that work in practice from those a little ahead of me in this area.

elements.text:

However, polling has the advantage that I can get the start of a market and my trades in that market with a single API call, whereas I would need to combine data from a stream with market data and an order stream.

I’m wondering how other people architect their applications to do this. Do you read both streams in a single loop? Or do you run each in its own process and share snapshots via a common cache? Do you initiate market streams for a single event, or leave them running all day choose within your application when you access the data? Do you use messaging to push data from the streams into a trading app, or pull data from a cache or other data store when needed?

Not expecting answers to all those questions … just hoping to get some insight in architectures that work in practice from those a little ahead of me in this area.

text: Just a quick answer for now but nothing wrong with combining polling and streaming IMHO

elements.text: Just a quick answer for now but nothing wrong with combining polling and streaming IMHO

text: I agree. Polling is certainly effective, but I'm wanting to reduce the lag that this causes when I'm looking for triggers in one market in order to trade in another.

elements.text: I agree. Polling is certainly effective, but I'm wanting to reduce the lag that this causes when I'm looking for triggers in one market in order to trade in another.

text: Lag because you're waiting for the response to listMarketBook?

elements.text: Lag because you're waiting for the response to listMarketBook?

text: I run the streams as separate processes (with trading apps as other processes) and use Redis pubsub for communication between them

elements.text: I run the streams as separate processes (with trading apps as other processes) and use Redis pubsub for communication between them

text: Multiple streams (market and order) + a FIFO queue, simple

elements.text: Multiple streams (market and order) + a FIFO queue, simple

text: <@UBS7QANF3> the lag to which I was referring was the time between an event occurring at Betfair and being pushed out in the stream and the timing of the next poll being requested. I've actually been pretty impressed by the speed of listMarketBook responses.

elements.text: the lag to which I was referring was the time between an event occurring at Betfair and being pushed out in the stream and the timing of the next poll being requested. I've actually been pretty impressed by the speed of listMarketBook responses.

text: Your question did though prompt me to think that for some strategies I could stream the markets and when an interesting situation occurs then do a quick poll on my orders before responding with trades. That would transition some of my strategies in the right direction.

elements.text: Your question did though prompt me to think that for some strategies I could stream the markets and when an interesting situation occurs then do a quick poll on my orders before responding with trades. That would transition some of my strategies in the right direction.

text: You dont need to poll for orders, just create an order stream and then .snap() it when you want an up to date order book

elements.text: You dont need to poll for orders, just create an order stream and then .snap() it when you want an up to date order book

text: <@UPEFBEEL8> A while back I was warned off by Betfair over excessive polling. Given a warning and told that my access would be removed without warning if it happened again. I suspect that the amount of polling I was doing was disproportionate to the trading volume that I was doing at the time. Since then I've been a bit more careful to not poll too frequently, and limit it to markets where I have a reasonable expectation to trade.

elements.text: A while back I was warned off by Betfair over excessive polling. Given a warning and told that my access would be removed without warning if it happened again. I suspect that the amount of polling I was doing was disproportionate to the trading volume that I was doing at the time. Since then I've been a bit more careful to not poll too frequently, and limit it to markets where I have a reasonable expectation to trade.

text: <@U4H19D1D2> Any time you write "its how I do it" I'm going to pay very close attention! Currently I process stream responses inside a while loop per the examples. Are you saying that I could simply instigate market and order streams in the same script, watch for market updates within a while loop, and then snap the orders listener within that loop when needed?
